Award.AwardTitle: GOALI: Volumetric Error Analysis of Machine Tools

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research objective of this Grant Opportunity for Academic Liaison with Industry (GOALI) project is to create a new, viable paradigm for machine tool calibration and geometric error compensation. Traditional calibration techniques take dense, accurate error measurements using laser interferometers over a very narrow range of the machine tool operating space. In this work laser trackers, which have reduced accuracy compared to laser interferometers, are used to take error measurements over the entire machine tool operating space, fundamentally altering the calibration problem landscape and requiring new methods for synthesizing and identifying kinematic models. Position-dependent six degree-of-freedom kinematic errors will be introduced and identified at each joint, along with quantified levels of accuracy. The constructed kinematic models will provide a foundation for the creation of new compensation methodologies for table-based and real-time systems. The new machine tool calibration and compensation tools will be combined into a holistic volumetric error analysis framework that will provide users with predictive tools capable of quantifying the tradeoffs involved when calibrating and compensating a machine tool.

The research results will generate the scientific and engineering knowledge needed to calibrate and compensate machine tools in a time-efficient manner over their entire operating space using complete, validated geometric error models. The decreased calibration costs, reduced part qualification time, and increased machine tool accuracy will allow a wide variety of products to be fabricated more cost-effectively and with superior quality, benefiting consumers, the economy, and society. This research project is a unique collaboration between Missouri University of Science and Technology, Boeing, MAG, Automated Precision Inc., and the Center for Aerospace Manufacturing Technologies. It will also provide exciting research opportunities for undergraduate students, promote learning opportunities for industrial practitioners, and broaden participation of underrepresented groups in engineering.

Institution.Name: Missouri University of Science and Technology

Performance_Institution.Name: Missouri University of Science and Technology

ProgramReference.Text: GRANT OPP FOR ACAD LIA W/INDUS
EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES
REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
The research objective of this GOALI project was to create a new, viable paradigm for the calibration and geometric error compensation of manufacturing machines (e.g., machine tools and robots). Traditional calibration techniques take dense, accurate geometric error measurements using laser interferometers over a very narrow range of the machine’s operating space. In this project, laser trackers were used to take error measurements over the entire operating space of the machine. This fundamentally alters the calibration problem landscape as it is inexpensive to gather geometric error measurements of the machine in any pose visible to the laser tracker, and requires new methods for synthesizing and identifying machine kinematic models. In this work, position-dependent six degree-of-freedom kinematic errors are identified at each machine joint, along with quantified levels of accuracy. The kinematic models provided a foundation for the creation of new machine tool table-based and robot inverse Jacobian-based compensation methodologies. The new machine calibration and compensation tools were combined into a holistic volumetric error analysis framework that provides users with predictive tools capable of quantifying the tradeoffs involved when calibrating and compensating manufacturing machines.

During this project the volumetric error compensation methodology has been applied to several industrial machine tools at Bell Helicopter, Boeing, and Caterpillar, as well as industrial robots at Automated Precision Inc., Bell Helicopter, FANUC, GE Power, and Toyota. The experimental results have shown the ability of the volumetric error compensation methodology to significantly decrease (i.e., by an order of magnitude) machine tool geometric errors, even when the number and combination of compensation tables is limited. The experimental results have also shown that the volumetric error compensation methodology can be applied to industrial robots to significantly reduce (i.e., an order of magnitude) their geometric errors. This work has generated six conference presentations and two published journal articles. Current work is investigating methods to robustly extrapolate error maps outside of the sensor’s visible range and to intelligently determine when a geometric error model has been invalidated. A software package for machine tools and robots has been created and the project team members are currently supporting Automated Precision Inc. to commercialize the package. The project provided research opportunities for five graduate students, including one female student who is now working at Boeing and implementing the calibration and compensation technologies created in this project, and four undergraduate students, including one minority student. Three of the undergraduate students decided to pursue PhD degrees in mechanical engineering.


Last Modified: 12/11/2017
Modified by: Robert G Landers

Traditional calibration techniques take dense, accurate geometric error measurements using laser interferometers over a very narrow range of the machine?s operating space. This fundamentally alters the calibration problem landscape as it is inexpensive to gather geometric error measurements of the machine in any pose visible to the laser tracker, and requires new methods for synthesizing and identifying machine kinematic models. The new machine calibration and compensation tools were combined into a holistic volumetric error analysis framework that provides users with predictive tools capable of quantifying the tradeoffs involved when calibrating and compensating manufacturing machines. The experimental results have shown the ability of the volumetric error compensation methodology to significantly decrease (i.e., by an order of magnitude) machine tool geometric errors, even when the number and combination of compensation tables is limited. The experimental results have also shown that the volumetric error compensation methodology can be applied to industrial robots to significantly reduce (i.e., an order of magnitude) their geometric errors. Current work is investigating methods to robustly extrapolate error maps outside of the sensor?s visible range and to intelligently determine when a geometric error model has been invalidated. A software package for machine tools and robots has been created and the project team members are currently supporting Automated Precision Inc. to commercialize the package. The project provided research opportunities for five graduate students, including one female student who is now working at Boeing and implementing the calibration and compensation technologies created in this project, and four undergraduate students, including one minority student.
